content.body: in reviewing MDN patches, I’ve run into cases where MDN article need to describe what happens with calling methods from `Date` objects that aren’t really dates
content.formatted_body: in reviewing MDN patches, I’ve run into cases where MDN article need to describe what happens with calling methods from Date objects that aren’t really dates

content.body: in the latest review I suggested wording it as *“if the Date object doesn’t represent a valid date”*
content.formatted_body: in the latest review I suggested wording it as “if the Date object doesn’t represent a valid date”

content.body: but I’m wondering if there’s some better way to describe it — I mean, without resorting to talking about internal slots of the object
congrats to Jamie Kyle on becoming delegate
content.formatted_body: congrats to Jamie Kyle on becoming delegate

content.body:
> <@sideshowbarker:mozilla.org> in the latest review I suggested wording it as *“if the Date object doesn’t represent a valid date”*

That's exactly how I'd say it...
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @sideshowbarker:mozilla.org
in the latest review I suggested wording it as “if the Date object doesn’t represent a valid date”
That's exactly how I'd say it...

content.body: Maybe even say "if the Date object doesn't point to a valid instant of time" or something like that...
content.formatted_body: Maybe even say "if the Date object doesn't point to a valid instant of time" or something like that...
